TEXT.English: Folklore - Old Man of the Forest
TEXT.French: Mythe de l'Ancien de la Forêt

TEXT.Italian: Mito dello squalo della barriera corallina

TEXT.French: Mythe de la Tortue de mer

TEXT.English: Folklore associated with formations found in the landscape.
TEXT.French: Les Mythes associés aux paysages et éléments trouvés dans la nature.
TEXT.Italian: Folklore associato con i rilievi presenti nel paesaggio.

TEXT.English: Cod is the common name for the genus Gadus of demersal fishes, belonging to the family Gadidae. Cod is also used as part of the common name for a number of other fish species, and there are species suggested to belong to genus Gadus that are not called cod (the Alaska pollock).[PARAGRAPH:2]The two most important species of cod are the Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua), which lives in the colder waters and deeper sea regions throughout the North Atlantic, and the Pacific cod (Gadus macrocephalus), found in both eastern and western regions of the northern Pacific. Gadus morhua was named by Linnaeus in 1758. (However, G. morhua callarias, a low-salinity, non-migratory race restricted to parts of the Baltic, was originally described as Gadus callarias by Linnaeus.)[PARAGRAPH:2]Cod is popular as a food with a mild flavour and a dense, flaky white flesh. Cod livers are processed to make cod liver oil, an important source of vitamin A, vitamin D, vitamin E and omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA). Young Atlantic cod or haddock prepared in strips for cooking is called scrod. In the United Kingdom, Atlantic cod is one of the most common ingredients in fish and chips, along with haddock and plaice.
TEXT.French: La morue est le nom commun du genre Gadus des poissons démersaux, appartenant à la famille des Gadidae. La morue est également utilisée dans le nom commun d'un certain nombre d'autres espèces de poissons, et il est suggéré que certaines espèces appartenant au genre Gadus ne soient pas appelées morue (goberge de l'Alaska).[PARAGRAPH:2]Les deux espèces les plus importantes de la morue est la morue de l'Atlantique (Gadus morhua), qui vit dans les eaux plus froides et les régions marines profondes de l'Atlantique Nord, et la morue du Pacifique (Gadus macrocephalus), que l'on trouve dans les régions de l'est et de l'ouest du nord du Pacifique. Gadus morhua a été nommé par Linnaeus en 1758. (Cependant, G. morhua callarias, une race non migratrice à faible salinité limitée à certaines parties de la Baltique, était à l'origine décrite comme Gadus callarias par Linnaeus.)[PARAGRAPH:2]Cod is populaire comme aliment avec une saveur douce et une chair blanche dense et feuilletée. Les foies de morue sont transformés pour faire de l'huile de foie de morue, une source importante de vitamine A, de vitamine D, de vitamine E et d'acides gras oméga-3 (EPA et DHA). La jeune morue franche ou aiglefin préparée en lanières pour la cuisson est appelée scrod. Au Royaume-Uni, la morue franche est l'un des ingrédients les plus courants dans le fish and chips, avec l'églefin et la plie.

TEXT.English: Crabs are decapod crustaceans of the infraorder Brachyura, which typically have a very short projecting "tail" (abdomen), usually entirely hidden under the thorax. They live in all the world's oceans, in fresh water, and on land, are generally covered with a thick exoskeleton and have a single pair of claws. Many other animals with similar names such as hermit crabs, king crabs, porcelain crabs, horseshoe crabs and crab lice are not true crabs.[PARAGRAPH:2]Crabs are generally covered with a thick exoskeleton, composed primarily of calcium carbonate, and armed with a single pair of chelae (claws). Crabs are found in all of the world's oceans, while many crabs live in fresh water and on land, particularly in tropical regions. Crabs vary in size from the pea crab, a few millimetres wide, to the Japanese spider crab, with a leg span of up to 4 metres (13 ft).[PARAGRAPH:2]About 850 species of crab are freshwater, terrestrial or semi-terrestrial species; they are found throughout the world's tropical and semi-tropical regions. They were previously thought to be a monophyletic group, but are now believed to represent at least two distinct lineages, one in the Old World and one in the New World.[PARAGRAPH:2]The earliest unambiguous crab fossils date from the Jurassic, although Carboniferous Imocaris, known only from its carapace, may be a primitive crab. The radiation of crabs in the Cretaceous and afterward may be linked either to the break-up of Gondwana or to the concurrent radiation of bony fish, crabs' main predators.

Mackerel is a common name applied to a number of different species of pelagic fish, mostly, but not exclusively, from the family Scombridae. They are found in both temperate and tropical seas, mostly living along the coast or offshore in the oceanic environment.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mackerel typically have vertical stripes on their backs and deeply forked tails. Many species are restricted in their distribution ranges, and live in separate populations or fish stocks based on geography. Some stocks migrate in large schools along the coast to suitable spawning grounds, where they spawn in fairly shallow waters. After spawning they return the way they came, in smaller schools, to suitable feeding grounds often near an area of upwelling. From there they may move offshore into deeper waters and spend the winter in relative inactivity. Other stocks migrate across oceans.[PARAGRAPH:2]Smaller mackerel are forage fish for larger predators, including larger mackerel and Atlantic cod. Flocks of seabirds, as well as whales, dolphins, sharks and schools of larger fish such as tuna and marlin follow mackerel schools and attack them in sophisticated and cooperative ways. Mackerel is high in omega-3 oils and is intensively harvested by humans. In 2009, over five million tons were landed by commercial fishermen (see graph on the right). Sport fishermen value the fighting abilities of the king mackerel.

A marlin is a fish from the family Istiophoridae (includes about 10 species). It has an elongated body, a spear-like snout or bill, and a long, rigid dorsal fin which extends forward to form a crest. Its common name is thought to derive from its resemblance to a sailor's marlin spike. Even more so than their close relatives, the scombrids, marlins are fast swimmers, reaching speeds of about 80 km/h (50 mph).[PARAGRAPH:2]The larger species include the Atlantic blue marlin, Makaira nigricans, which can reach 5 m (16.4 ft) in length and 818 kg (1,803 lb) in weight and the black marlin, Istiompax indica, which can reach in excess of 5 m (16.4 ft) in length and 670 kg (1,480 lb) in weight. They are popular sporting fish in tropical areas.

The eagle rays are a group of cartilaginous fishes in the family Myliobatidae, consisting mostly of large species living in the open ocean rather than on the sea bottom.[PARAGRAPH:2]Eagle rays feed on mollusks and crustaceans, crushing their shells with their flattened teeth. Devil and manta rays filter plankton from the water. They are excellent swimmers and are able to breach the water up to several metres above the surface. Compared with other rays, they have long tails, and well-defined rhomboidal bodies. They are ovoviviparous, giving birth to up to six young at a time. They range from 0.48 to 9.1 m (1.6 to 29.9 ft) in length.
TEXT.German: Als [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Adlerrochen[COLOR_REVERT] bezeichnet man mehrere Arten aus der Gattung Aetobatus und der Familie Myliobatidae. Bis 2016 gehörten alle derselben Familie an. Man findet sie vorwiegend in tropischen und subtropischen Gewässern. Der Gewöhnliche Adlerrochen als häufigste Art ist bereits ab und an in den Sommermonaten als Irrgast in der Nordsee gesichtet worden.[NEWLINE]Adlerrochen sind sehr groß und können bis zu drei Meter breit werden. Der rhombische Rumpf ist kräftig und der Kopf steht deutlich hervor. Die Augen sitzen seitlich. Die Spritzlöcher sind bei Myliobatidae von oben nicht sichtbar. Das breite Maul befindet sich auf der Unterseite, wobei sich bei Aeobatus nur je eine Zahnreihe an Ober- und Unterkiefer befindet, bei Myliobatidae sind es mehrere Reihen. Der Schwanz ist lang und peitschenartig. Ihre Nahrung besteht hauptsächlich aus Mollusken und Krustentieren.

TEXT.French: Voir [LINK=UNIT_MACKEREL]Maquereau[/LINK] car les thons sont une espèce de Maquereaux.
